Hopefully, you know since you came to
this talk, but maybe you don't. So, an
RTS, which is a genre I've worked in a
fair bit, is defined by a couple things.
It has an omnisient view with a free
roaming camera, meaning unlike things
like Fortnite, it is not tied to a
player character. You are not
controlling a character. You're instead
controlling, as I put very dramatically
on the slide, ravening hordes of units.
You control them with group selection
and then you support them with
structures, which means production
structures, which build the units and
resource structures, which yeah, you pay
for them with and usually there are
secondary tertiary structures as well.
So, uh, we have a couple of those,
mostly our player base, but that's sort
of the heart of it. Then there's game
balance, which I refer to as the combat
tri triangle, which is really sort of
rock, paper, scissors. Light units that
move fast, don't take much damage, don't
put out much damage, are good for
scouting. Medium units that are
somewhere in the middle, and then heavy
units, slow, do a lot of damage, take a
lot of damage. And usually you balance
those three against each other to build
out your core strategy. And then
finally, while there is a lot of really
good campaign content in an RTS, it is a
primarily multiplayer driven genre, and
that's what we built here is a
two-player multiplayer game. So, to
further illustrate our point, I'm going
to run a little trailer for you
with rocking music.
more later.

User interface is a huge focus for us
obviously with a game like this because
an RTS is inherently user interfaced
driven because you're not controlling a
player. You're basically using an UI to
drive your game world. Players need to
group select and move units. They need
to select production structures, add
more units to their build queue, which
is how units are built, and then check
their resources to make sure they have
necessary credits. For unit selection,
we went with what I think of as a const
style methodology, which you can see in
this video. Meaning, what you're doing
is you're drawing a 2D box from the
center screen.
And then when you release your basically
hold input, when you release it,
whatever the size of the box is, we
translate that from 2D to 3D. and then
select all the units in the box. And we
the reason we did this versus your
traditional sort of RTS drag select is
because we wanted this to work across
all platforms, not just on PC. So it
works on your phone, it works on a
console, it works on PC. It's always the
same interface. And how that works is we
use two verse devices. One to draw the
box and then the one that takes the
dimensions of that box, identifies units
within its bounds, and selects them. And
the first is quite simple. It just uses
Verse UI to draw a scaling box. When you
hold in the button, runs a loop that
starts doing that. When you release it,
it finishes and then sends the bounds of
the box translated from 2D to 3D
to the actual unit selection device. So,

first, I want to talk about how you
control structures cuz we had to do some

talking about the setup. So, we went
with a structure capture system for our
game. Many RTS's focus on building the
structures yourself, but given our time
limits, we wanted to keep things a bit
simpler and a bit less fiddly cuz that's
an immense amount of work and we only
had so much time. And it also makes it
just easier to play for people who are
more entry- level gamers. So it was the
system we went with. The capture logic
is conceptually quite simple. You can
see it happening here. Basically a unit
start a production structure starts out
uncaptured. You can see it is white. And
then when a player moves units into the
radius of the structure to initiate a
time capture sequence. Once that timer
completes the capturing player takes
control of the structure itself. And if
the player's units leave the zone or are
destroyed before the timer completes,
the capture sequence is canceled out.
The captured structure can also be
captured by another side. Once you own
it, doesn't mean it's yours forever.
Though there was a bug where for a while
it was yours forever. Uh moving on. Uh
as I discovered and then exploited so I
could beat Floren. Um but yeah, so you
have to defend your buildings. So how
this works is a mixture of devices and
some verse code. All right. So what we
do is we use a mutator zone device, a
timer device, and whatever structures we
actually capture, they are all
referenced by something called a
structure capture device because what we
didn't want to do is build the capture
logic into each device or into each
structure because then you have a lot of
redundant code. So this is just good UFN
practice is you build a structure
capture device in our case that has all
the code. It handles the mutator zone.
It handles the timer and it contains a
list of the structures you can capture.
And what we do is once the timer has
completed, we have a list of the
structures that can be captured by that
particular capture device. It's usually
one, can be more. And we send an
interface call to that structure that
executes an interface command, a
function essentially that we have an
interface called capturable. And if you
are capturable, you'll be able to
execute a function that says I've been
captured by this player. And that
contains what bespoke logic we have. So
trying to show you the video. We'll do
it. There we go. So what mostly what
that does is it does things like setting
the material instances so you know who
controls a structure. We have different
colors. See it turns green because
player one captured it. Sends that HUD
message. And then if you're a resource
structure, it activates the resource
loop for your resource tick. If you're
captured then by a different player, we
shut down that loop and relaunch it
pointing at the other resource manager.
Production structures, what it does is
it basically says you are controlled by
this player. we must activate these
spawners because we use spawners for the
actual production. So it turns on the
basically logic of the structure when
you capture it. If it's captured by a
different player, we run that logic
again and set it up for the other
player. And that is structure capture.

the first entry in the array and that is

integer from the array and thus the
build queue moves down one. And you can
have up to five units in your build
queue, which is an arbitrary number, but
because we wanted to get to 45 units
max, we didn't want you to just queue up
900 units. I also have a hard build cap
